title: I received a: Notice of Trustee's intent to compromise controversy.
question: The persons named filed for bk 7, they owed me some money. what do I need to do?
answers: Nothing really, though it's possible that there might be some distribution from the bankruptcy estate to creditors. If you have been given notice to file a claim, you should have done that. Otherwise, if you have not decided to bring an adversary proceeding against the debtor (which you probably didn't), there's not much else you can do.

As I understand it, you are owed money, the person who owes you the money filed a Chapter 7 BK, and you have now received notices from the Ch 7 Trustee that you do not understand.

Without more context, it is difficult to answer your question fully. Is this a "no asset" case (meaning that the debtor does not have any non-exempt assets to distribute to creditors like yourself)? Has an adversarial proceeding been filed by the Trustee, and if so, on what grounds? What exactly is the Trustee attempting to compromise? How much money or you owed? Is there any fraud involved? You
will need to find answers to these questions.

My best advice is two-fold. First, DO NOT contact the debtor directly, or you will risk getting in big trouble by violating the BK stay. It is tough when individuals are owed money and a debtor in BK is protected by a stay that stops the creditor from trying to collect the debt. Nevertheless, that is the law, most of the time. Secondly, you should contact a competent attorney who can check the status of the case for you online, through a system called PACER. The attorney can then provide you with proper advice, after looking at all of the details of your case. You may have to file a “proof of claim”, but if there are no assets to distribute, that probably will not be necessary. If you go to the Federal BK court in person, you will be able to get access to the PACER system even though you are not an attorney. The problem is, you will likely be baffled by what you see - - it can be complicated and hard to understand for people who are not trained in this area. Contact an attorney -- many attorneys will offer a brief consultation for free, before you retain them.

Good luck in your pursuit of justice!

Sincerely,
Mark Joshua Gordon
Los Angeles, CA

The notice is sent to all creditors in compliance with the Bankruptcy rules.

Apparently, the Trustee has entered into a settlement either with the debtors or other creditors regarding a claim or lawsuit. Read the document over to see what it says. Depending on whether the Trustee also sent a copy of the motion (and perhaps the settlement document), you might learn a little about what is going on with the case. You are certainly entitled to call the Trustee to ask about the status of the case generally and possibility of a distribution to a creditor such as yourself. Trustees and their lawyers always expect creditors like you to contact them after receiving a notice like this.

You are free to object to the settlement or compromise, but that is only recommended if you have some sort of involvement or knowledge about the dispute being resolved and you have a sufficiently large claim that would benefit. Routinely, these settlements are unopposed.

The bottom line is that the notice lets you know there is activity in the case. The fact that you received the notice is proof that the Trustee/Court has your current mailing address.
